lines.text: That was a wonderful supper, Tembo. I'm full and happy, and not afraid anymore.
To be not afraid is to be careless.

[to Komba the bushbaby]
What is there to fear, eh, Komba?
The galago fears little because he knows little. The lion is wise and fears much because he knows much.

[to Komba]
Did you hear what he said? He thinks you're stupid. You're not stupid, are you, Komba?
I'm sorry, Tembo. I should have listened and gone to the police like you said.
"All the yesterdays cannot make one tomorrow."

[to Tembo from a distance]
I'll see you hanged for this, you bloody devil. You mark my words. There's still some law and order left in this country!
Your wife was killed in the uprising.
That was an accident.
In 1956 your houseboy, Tembo Murumbi, was suspected of Mau Mau activities.

[irritated]
What are you trying to say?
We all know the African mentality.
Do we?
It's very likely that he has a resentment against you.
No...
You do admit the possibility?

[after walking into Jackie's cabin and discovering something moving inside a basket]
Blimey!
It's alright, I can make up my own bed.
What in heaven's name you got in there, miss?
Nothing...
Well, a bit noisy for nothing.
I'll show you if you promise not to say anything.
It ain't a snake, is it?
No.
[pulls out Komba the galago]
Bushbaby!
Queer, ain't it? It looks a bit like a monkey!
Would you like to hold him? He's very gentle.

[hesitatingly]
I'll take your word for it, miss.

[Jackie and her father are standing next to a gravestone marked "In loving memory of Penelope Leeds, who died in the uprising of 1961"]
I've arranged for Tembo to keep the flowers watered.
I wish Tembo were coming with us.
He'll be at the boat to see us off.
[noticing Jackie's discontentment]
Jackie... Tembo belongs in Africa.
Like Komba?
[she walks away from her father]
I belong here, too. I was born here. I don't want to go away.
It can't be helped Jackie. I don't want to leave Africa any more than you do.
It isn't only Africa, I have to leave everything!
If it is Tembo with Jackie, I don't want him arrested. You know what would happen.
Isn't the important thing your daughter's safety?
If she is with Tembo she is safe.

[after Komba has disrupted the choir song]
Is that the devil in our midst, miss Leeds? Or as I suspect, a heavenly cherub.
[the members of the church laugh]
Since it appears the Christian soldiers have lost the battle to a bushbaby, I suggest you all take your seats and we shall continue the service.

[after Jackie wakes up]
Do you feel better, mtoto?
Mm, much better. I'm not hot anymore.

[in approval]
Hm.
The pain in my arm's gone.

[again in approval]
Hmm!
Oh, where's Cranky?
Do not be angry, but I could not let him take you in his airship because many times I've heard your father say that it is not safe. So I took you from that place when he was not looking.

[with surprise at the object Tembo is now carrying]
Where did you get the gun?
I took it from the bwana doctor.
Why I hope you didn't hurt poor old Cranky.
Why should I hurt him? He's only a foolish old man. I only took the gun so he would not hurt me.
[last lines]
Kwaheri, Komba!
[first lines]

[Jackie and Tembo are chasing a small galago around a baobab tree]
Where is he?
Sshh!

[after Tembo catches the creature he hands it to Jackie]
Oh! Oh, he's so tiny!
He's a young one.
What shall I call him?
bushbaby, galago... In Swahili he's called "Komba."
Komba! That's marvelous.
[to Komba]
Hey Komba, Komba...!
[to Tembo]
Oh, thank you, Tembo. Asante sana!
Stahere, mtoto.
They have no reason to kill me; I've done nothing.
My mother did nothing.
Are you sure you know this place?
Of course I do; I spent many holidays here. The cottage's up this way and the village is over there. So, stop worrying.
I will stop when you're in the ship with your baba and I'm in the bush.
